name: Pavamana Mantra
Benefits: increase mental clairty, cultivate non-attachement, remove the fear of death, and make you rise above the self-limiting identities
Significance: This mantra very succinctly spells out what the spiritual evolution is all about. It appears orginially in the Brihadaranyaka Upanishad to invoke Soma, one of the pricipal vedic deities, as Brahman, the supreme being, to guide the seeker toward the ultimate truth. The world as we tend to experience and tend to relate is nothing but Asat or in other words has no true substance and can never truly satisfy us. Therfore, we must seek Sat, that which true and that which is permanent. The mantra proclaims that the journey from Asat to Sat is also the journey from darkness (limited vision) to the light and from death (limited identification) to immortality.
How to chant: This mantra has become very popular across yoga ashrams and meditation centres as a closing affirmation after individual or joint activities. across This is a sadhaka mantra (practioner's mantra) and should be recited at the beginning of daily yoga practice. Knowing not only its words and pronunciation but also its meaning and significance is crucial to make this a remarkably powerful invocation.
mantra: asato, mA, sadgamaya; tamaso, mA, jyotirgamaya; mR^ityormA, amR^itaM, gamaya; OM, shAntiH, shAntiH, shAntiH
wordenglish: asataH=from unreal, mA=me, sat=real / gamaya=lead; tamasaH=from darkness, mA=me, jyotiH=the light / gamaya=lead; mR^ityoH=from death / mA=me, amR^itaM=immortality, gamaya=lead;  OM=om, shAntiH=peace, shAntiH=peace, shAntiH=peace
mantraenglish:
Lead me from unreal to the real
Lead me from darkness to the light
Lead me from (the fear of) death to (the knowledge of) immortality.
Om! Peace, peace peace!

name: Chandrashekhar Ashtakam
Significance: This highly revered mantra invokes the Sun God (Savitr) through our inner light to bless us with illumination and self-knowledge. The Gayatri mantra together with the Mahamrityunjaya mantra are considered the most special and thought to embed all of the mantra shakti. This mantra is a must before any knowledge seeking endeavor. Traditionally, this mantra was given by the teacher to the pupil as part of the threading ceremony right before starting the formal education, like a right of passage.
How to chant: This mantra can be chanted anywhere and anytime, but it will incur the highest benefit when chanted during the early morning period (bramha muhurta). For the beginners, the correct vedic pronunciation with svaras can provide a noticeably deeper inner experience. Meditators should chant it at the beginning of their meditation session. A very common practice is to chant the gayatri mantra 108 times in a single session (one mala of Gayatri). This mantra is often used for Purashcharan (the practice of chanting the mantra 100008 times under the guidance of a spiritual guide).

mantraenglish: Lord Shiva! Lord Shiva! Lord Shiva guide me! Lord Shiva! Lord Shiva! Lord Shiva protect me!

I seek refuge in Him, who has the moon as his crown, who made the mountain of jewels into his bow, who resides on the moutain of silver, who made the serpent lord Vasuki into the bow-string, who made Lord Vishnu as the arrow and quickly destroyed the three floating cities, who is saluted by the three worlds, and so what can the God of death do to me?

I seek refuge in Him, who has the moon as his crown, whose two lotus-like feet shine with the fragrance of flowers from the five holy plants, who burnt the body of Kama, the God of desire, by the fire emanating from his third eye, whose body is smeared with ash, who is the destroyer of the sorrows of this life, who exists eternally, and so what can the God of death do to me?

I seek refuge in Him, who has the moon as his crown, who wears the skin of the intoxicated bull elephant and looks enchanting, whose lotus-like feet are worshipeed by Lord Brahma and Lord Vishnu, whose beautifully matted locks of hair are drenched in the mist rising from the water waves of Ganges, and so what can the God of death do to me?

I seek refuge in Him, who has the moon as his crown, who is Kubera's friend, who plucked the eyes of Bhaga, who wears serpents as ornaments, whose left body is surrounded by beautiful Parvati, whose throat is dark blue from the poison he drank, who holds the axe in his hand, who holds the deer in his hand, and so what can the God of death do to me?

I seek refuge in Him, who has the moon as his crown, who wears serpents as earings and goes by the name of Kundaleshvara, who has the bull as his vehicle, whose splendor has been praised by the great sages such as Narada, who is the wish fulfilling tree to his devotees, who is the killer of the death itself, and so what can the God of death do to me?

I seek refuge in Him,  who has the moon as his crown, who is the medicine for those suffering from the life's sorrows, who is the remover of all misfortunes, who destroyed Daksha's fire sacrifice, who is the personification of three gunas, who has three eyes, who is the bestower of enjoyment and liberation, who is the annihilator of all evils, and so what can the God of death do to me?

I seek refuge in Him, who has the moon as his crown, who is loving to the devotees, who is the inexhaustible treasure that is worshipped by all, who has the sky as his garment, who is the master of all beings, who is beyond all, who is unfathomable, who is unsrupassed, who created sun, moon, water, earth, fire, air and ether, and so what can the God of death do to me?

I seek refuge in Him, who has the moon as his crown, who performs the creation of the universe, who again is also devoted to its maintenance, and who even destroys the manifested universe, who resides in all beings, who is continually playing in the creation, who is the leader of all but also like the rest, and so what can the God of death do to me?
